history.content:
At the beginning of the class you get to choose between a test-only grading option, and a tests + homework grading option. I highly recommend doing the homework, and having the additional motivation of part-of-your-grade-depends-on-it may help you to consistently do the homework. Also, go to class or watch videos as soon as they're released -- if you fall behind it can be very difficult to catch up (especially if you don't enjoy math).

----------------------------------------

If you absolutely NEED a B+ or higher at all costs for CS70, to declare CS I assume, maybe it's worth taking even more advanced classes before you take CS70. Stats 134 will have all you all covered for CS70's probability section, and an upper div math like 110 or 113 can help you with the proofs. Your overall GPA may take a hit, or you can take those advanced classes P/NP, but if only your grade in CS70 that absolutely matters, it may well be worth the sacrifice to help you declare.

----------------------------------------

Absolutely agree with the second anon. Going to CS 70 with some background is so much easier to follow the class, that way you don't have to worry about spending way too much time on CS 70 and not enough time on other classes. I would say taking STAT 134 is worth it if OP has time for it.

Also, go to class or watch videos as soon as they're released -- if you fall behind it can be very difficult to catch up (especially if you don't enjoy math).

----------------------------------------

children.subject: The probability in Data8 was pretty slow and basic. I don't think it would help for cs70. I haven't taken stat140, so that might help.
+1 best RAm

One way I succeeded was actually taking a stat class alongside CS70. Classes like data8 or stat140 alongside CS70 will really drive some of the probability concepts into your head. It might seem a bit excessive to take an extra class just to do better in CS70, but for declaration I found it worthwhile.
Are you Sinho Chewi?
Nooo :P I'm flattered that you think so because from what I can tell Sinho's pretty amazing. But you probably haven't heard of me.
Sinho Chewi is a BOSS.
What is a "CSM section"?
Computer Science Mentors. They provide extra help to students. Make sure to sign up as soon as they open up because they do get full within an hour.

This is our website. If you don't immediately get into a section, be sure to sign up for the waitlist because a few weeks in we drop everyone with unexcused absences. At least for 70, I don't think we fill up that fast; last semester my impression was like 1-2 days. Again, the offer to remind you on this thread when registration opens still stands.

Please do remind us on this thread when the sections will open up. Do you have a rough idea of when that will happen? Will it be sometime after the semester has started? 

What's the official method of finding out about when it's time to enroll into the CSM sections?

Ok, I'll do that!

You should be able to sign up sometime in the second week (week of 1/23) after all mentors have picked their sections. So not the very beginning of the week but sometime in the second week. There's no official method (that I know of) but we will ask course staff to make an instructor note on the CS 70 Piazza after sections open. Mentoring will start in the third week.

If you want another unit or you think a 5-person section for extra help / mentoring in general is your thing, you can sign up for a CSM section. (Shameless plug lol. But still, if you want I'll let you know on this thread when registration opens. It'll also be posted on the CS 70 piazza. (Also if you're reading this thread bc you liked 70 and you want to teach, you can apply to be a junior mentor!!)) It's 1.5 hours or extra practice / concept review a week and you don't need to prepare or anything, just show up.

But here's my other advice: read the notes, take note of the definitions (really those are important, there's no point of proving something if you don't know what exactly you're trying to prove), write down your questions as you get them when reading the notes. Question every statement in a proof and try to find the motivation behind doing things a certain way. If you can't find why you can make a statement or why something is done a certain way--bam, that's a question, write it down. Maybe eventually you can find the answers to those questions yourself, but the questions are a way of figuring out exactly what holes you have, and if you can't figure it out after a few hours on a note, ask a TA or a friend or on Piazza. If you don't know the exact definition of something, that's also a question. Write down the definition you don't know, look it up, then write down the definition, then memorize it. You should know definitions cold. Don't take too many other hard classes if you don't have much of a math background---intuition (which is basically "mathematical maturity") is very helpful and is built up by just spending a lot of time on math. 

I think that Alvin Wan (the head TA) and others have written their own resources to help you. There's lots of midterm practice stuff. So for test practice / resources you're basically set--you're probably not going to run out of practice. On the more conceptual side, I'm writing something along the lines of "70, but in English, so for people who don't have that much math experience," but it's taking fairly long. 

Also if you don't enjoy math, I hope you can come into 70 with an open mind; it's most likely different from any math class you've previously taken. Maybe 70 will change your mind about math---I truly hope you'll maybe see parts of it as neat or cool or, dare I say, beautiful. I think it's beautiful, but past that, CS in general is a lot of math and you might find some future classes more enjoyable (or less distateful, whichever you want) if you like math. I understand if you don't like it still though.

...I hope this was helpful or will be to someone, because it'd be a little embarrassing to have written this much and for it not to be helpful. 

I wish you the very best of luck!

^ This is very important. My friends that went into the class with a closed mind hated every minute of it because they refused to see how interesting the class was. I'm certainly not a math person, and I struggled through every concept in 70, but because I went in with the right mindset is was (I daresay) an enjoyable experience.

All of the previous advice for studying is good, so in particular, I'd like to stress coming into 70 with an open mind like the anon above said. I came in curious but not yet fully convinced about the beauty of math, but by the end, I was totally sold. (It was mostly the countability/computability stuff in my case.) It's definitely a different type of math than what I've encountered before, and I'm really glad I got to take the course. And, for me, it also taught new ways to think about and approach problems.

Moreover, I think in general, having an open mind towards new material is gonna be valuable because the more you close yourself off from appreciating it - due to preconceived notions, continued frustrations, etc - the harder it's going to be to absorb. So in other words, don't knock it until you've given it a fair shot. You might still not like it that much in the end, but being cynical won't necessarily help you. Regardless, good luck!

when you do this, make sure to do hw problems and midterm questions along the side, because otherwise it's very hard to remember the slides. This is a mistake I made when I was preparing before the class started.
Soroush is interning at facebook.
My point is, he has credibility.
Start reading the notes and lectures from previous semester now... CS 70 goes by so fast that if you don't have any previous proof/probability background you will easily fall behind

I TA'd 70 the past two semesters. Best advice for problem solving classes like these is to spend a lot of time on the problems, and then afterwards on reflecting on your problem solving process. Reflect on which techniques moved you in the right direction, how these techniques are similar to other techniques or how you approached different but similar problems, and which techniques don't work for the particular problem (and why they don't work). This goes a long ways in building intuition, which I think is the hardest part about 70 and the part you can take the most from as you move on to more challenging material. It's hard and a bit painful to do this, but definitely worth it in the long run.

Also, go to discussions! Definitely try different TAs to figure out a style that works for you and then stick with it.
I would listen to Soroush. He is interning at Facebook over the summer.

IMO, doing practice is very important but understanding the concepts is more time efficient and more rewarding. Discussion worksheets are useful for test prep. Of course this method works for some (as indicated by this response), but some of my students expressed frustration and disappointment at this bc it felt hallow and unrewarding since they didn't understand the concepts as well.

At the same time if you find yourself doing practice tests and having to stare at the solutions the whole time, I'd advise revisiting the notes and discussions (especially for the proofs part, the notes are essential).

Hi Soroush, 

Congratulations on getting an offer at Facebook! Thats funny though, that's the kind of stuff my friends and I would do to each other all the time. 

But in all seriousness, I not only have a question about CS70, but more specifically, how you managed to do well in CS70 while internship recruiting. I spent a good amount of time recruiting with various companies this past semester, and that took a toll on my grades. To make it worse, I didn't get any offers. 

How were you able to put in all the time for HW problems, studying, doing ALL of the practice exams, etc. and making time for recruiting and any other extracurriculars that you are doing? 

Also, you don't have too, but any recruiting tips would help too. 

Thanks!

The best way to succeed imo is to do lots of (I mean every single one) practice tests because that is the best indicator of what kind of questions you will see on the midterms. I think the midterms follow a strict formula that you can master, and the best way to master that formula is past tests. Don't spend too much time being bogged in the class slides, but do take the discussion worksheets seriously.

After having written the rest of this response, I decided that this bit of advice is more important: "Never let yourself believe that you can't learn the material." The rest of this response assumes that you never give up on trying to learn the material. If you give up, you enter into a positive feedback cycle where you think you can't do it, so you fall behind, and then you really can't do it, which makes you fall behind further.

There have been a variety of different answers that have all worked for the people who posted them. My own take on it is that for CS 70, you really need to be comfortable with the material. It's not quite like 61A or 61B or 61C where a lot of what you learn is just how some aspect of a computer works. With 70, you'll be building on the mathematical foundation you already have and you'll be using just about all of it. You need to creatively use what skills you have in order to solve CS 70 problems. The only way to get to that level of comfort is to sit down with the material and think about it. The way I gauged my comfort level with the material was seeing if I could build back up to a topic from first principles. For example,

"How does secret sharing work?"

"You distribute your secret as points on a polynomial."

"Why do you do that?"

"Because n points define a degree n-1 polynomial uniquely. There are an infinite number of ways to construct a degree n-1 polynomial with only n-1 points."

"I guess that means if you take a degree n-1 polynomial, make the secret $$P(0)$$ and give a unique point on that polynomial to each of n unique people, then that group of n people wouldn't be able to reconstruct the polynomial unless they all come together. Without reconstructing the polynomial, there's no way they can access the secret at $$P(0)$$, so it's safe."

Of course, first principles depends on your mathematical background. Maybe you'd need to go a step further or a step less than I did, but the point is that you should understand exactly what each topic is doing and why it works. With some topics, you might need some more practice to get more comfortable with it, like counting or random variables. Regardless, this method worked well for me in 70 and should get you more than just a B+ if you follow through.

I was a TA for 70 one semester if that's important.

history.content: I don't particularly enjoy math but I want to be declared. Any study strategies and resources to help me achieve a B+ or higher would be appreciated.
history.subject: How to Slay CS70
